title: Augusta County: John Scott to E. P. Smith, February 1, 1869
summary: Discussing the success of an AMA "Sabbath School" in Staunton, Scott states, "Since our arrival, thirty new scholars have been added to the school and it really begins to appear like a northern school except the color." In much of the letter, Scott outlines his many grievances against a black preacher in town who he claims has shown "opposition to our work." In the concluding paragraph of the correspondence, Scott tells the story of a student named Mary who had been "Bound Out" by the local authorities.
keywords: African Americans, Education, Church/Religious Activity, Economy, Race Relations, American Civil War
